What does the glomerulus do ?: The glomerulus is the main filtering unit of the kidney, where blood is filtered to produce urine.
What are the direct targets of the olfac: The direct targets of the olfactory tract are the piriform cortex, amygdala, and entorhinal cortex.
What are the indirect targets of the olf: The indirect targets of the olfactory tract include the hypothalamus, amygdala, and several regions of the cerebral cortex through projections from the pyriform cortex and other forebrain areas through the thalamus.
Give examples of neurodegenerative disor: Some examples of neurodegenerative disorders include Alzheimer's disease, Lou Gehrig's disease (ALS), Parkinson's disease, Huntington's disease, and Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS).
What are the main indications of neurode: The main indications of neurodegenerative disorders include neuron loss, protein aggregation, and cognitive decline. Some common examples include Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease, and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).
What is the most common neurodegenerativ: The most common neurodegenerative disorder is Alzheimer's disease.
Define dementia:: Dementia is an umbrella term for a range of neurological conditions that cause a decline in cognitive abilities, affecting memory, thinking, behavior, and motor control. The most common type of dementia is Alzheimer's disease, which is caused by a buildup of plaque in the brain.
Why are the pathological markers of AD?: The pathological markers of Alzheimer's disease (AD) are amyloid- (A) peptide deposition and neurofibrillary tangles, which are primarily composed of tau protein. These pathological changes are caused by the accumulation of A peptides in the brain, leading to neuronal degeneration and loss of function.
What are the pathological markers of PD?: The most sensitive pathological marker of Parkinson's disease (PD) is Nigrosome-1, which indicates the area of maximal dopamine depletion. Additionally, there is a significant loss of dopaminergic cells, estimated at 40-60%. Lipid dysregulation is also involved in various pathological processes in PD.
What are the pathological markers of PSP: The pathological markers of PSP are a predominance of 4-repeat (4R) tau inclusions in the form of neurofibrillary tangles. The extent of tau pathology is used as a surrogate marker for pathological severity in patients with PSP.
What are the pathological markers of CBG: The pathological markers of corticobasal degeneration (CBGD) are tau-immunoreactive lesions in the brain. These lesions help to distinguish CBGD from other tauopathies such as Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease.
What are the pathological markers of Hun: The pathological markers of Huntington's disease include aggregates of the mutant huntingtin protein, which are found in the nucleus and cytoplasm of neurons, as well as reactive gliosis in glial cells.
What are the pathological markers of pic: The pathological markers of Pick's disease include argyrophilic, round intraneuronal inclusions called Pick bodies. Additionally, there is an abundance of mature tau pathology markers, particularly 3R tau-positive and 4R tau-negative, in frontotemporal limbic/paralimbic regions.
What was PD first described as ?: Parkinson's disease was first described as a "shaking palsy" by Dr. James Parkinson in 1817.
What does PD cause ?: Parkinson's disease (PD) causes a gradual loss of brain cells that produce dopamine, leading to movement problems and other symptoms.
Do patients normally die form PD and wha: Patients with Parkinson's disease (PD) typically do not die from the disease itself, but rather from other conditions such as heart disease, stroke, or cancer. Most people with PD have a normal or near-normal life expectancy, with survival rates being the same as the general population or shortened by about a year. End-stage PD has a life expectancy of 6-12 months.
What are the main symptoms of Parkinson: The main symptoms of Parkinson disease are tremor, slowness of movement (bradykinesia), and rigidity.
What do Parkinson\u2019s patients do to: Parkinson's patients may try counting '1-2-3-go', shifting their weight side to side, or marching in place before stepping forward to help initiate movements.
What are the pathological effects of Par: Parkinson's disease is characterized by the progressive loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra, resulting in movement disorders such as bradykinesia, resting tremor, and rigidity. Additionally, the accumulation of aggregated -synuclein in various parts of the brain and peripheral organs can also contribute to the disease.
What are the causes of Parkinson\u2019s: The exact cause of Parkinson's disease is not fully understood, but it is believed to be caused by the breakdown or death of dopamine-producing neurons in the brain. Genetic factors, such as mutations in the LRRK2 gene, are believed to play a role in about 15% of cases. Other factors, such as environmental factors such as smoking and certain medications, may also play a role in the development of Parkinson's disease.
What things have caused associated disor: There are several things that have been associated with Parkinson's disease, including genetic mutations in the LRRK2 gene, repeated head trauma, and certain medications.
What happens to the pathways in Parkinso: In Parkinson's disease, there is a progressive loss of dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta, a region of the brain responsible for coordinating movement. This leads to a decrease in the supply of dopamine to the motor cortex, which is involved in movement control. Additionally, there is a buildup of -synuclein-containing protein aggregates, known as Lewy bodies, in the affected neurons.
Describe huntingtons disease: Huntington's disease is a rare, inherited neurodegenerative condition that causes progressive deterioration of brain cells. Symptoms include involuntary movements, mood changes, and cognitive decline. The disease is caused by a genetic mutation, and individuals with the mutation have a 50% chance of passing it on to their children.
What are the symptoms that lead to demen: The symptoms that lead to dementia in Huntington's disease include a decline in memory, thinking, and reasoning skills, as well as changes in mood and behavior such as depression, anxiety, and irritability.
What are th symptoms that lead to gross: The symptoms that lead to gross choreiform movements of Huntington's disease include involuntary muscle movements, fidgetiness, clumsiness, and difficulty with speech, swallowing, and gait.
Where are neurons lost in huntingtons di: In Huntington's disease, neurons are lost primarily in the striatum, specifically in the striosomes.
Which neurons are the first to be affect: The first neurons to be affected in Huntington's disease are those in the striatum, which is a part of the basal ganglia.
What happens to neurotransmitters in hun: In Huntington's disease, there is a decrease in the levels of neurotransmitters such as gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) and substance P. This is due to the degeneration of inhibitory medium spiny neurons in the corpus striatum.
What happens to the pathway in huntingto: In Huntington's disease, the pathway is disrupted due to a mutation in the gene encoding for the huntingtin protein. This mutation causes the huntingtin protein to expand, forming aggregates that block axons and sequester motor proteins, leading to neuronal dysfunction and neurodegeneration.
What are the causes of huntingtons disea: Huntington's disease is caused by an inherited gene mutation that leads to the degeneration of nerve cells in certain regions of the brain.
Describe progressive supranuclear palsy: Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a rare neurodegenerative disorder that affects movement, balance, eye movements, and cognition. It is caused by damage to nerve cells in specific areas of the brain that control these functions. Symptoms include loss of balance, slowing of movement, difficulty moving the eyes, and cognitive impairment.
What are the main symptoms of PSP?: The main symptoms of PSP (Progressive Supranuclear Palsy) include problems with balance and mobility, such as frequent falls, changes in behavior such as irritability or apathy, difficulty swallowing, and a fixed or startled facial expression.
What is opthalmoplegia ?: Ophthalmoplegia is the paralysis or weakness of the eye muscles, affecting one or more of the six muscles that control eye movement.
What balance/postural impairments occur: In PSP, balance and postural impairments include gait instability, a tendency to fall in any direction, and a broad-based walking pattern.
What are he pseudobulbar palsy symptoms: The pseudobulbar palsy symptoms of PSP include difficulty swallowing, slurred speech, and outbursts of uncontrolled laughter or crying.
What are the pathologies of PSP?: Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP) is characterized by neurofibrillary tangles, neuronal loss, and gliosis affecting the basal ganglia, brainstem, cerebellum, and cerebral cortex.
What are neurofibrillary tangles ?: Neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs) are intracellular aggregates of hyperphosphorylated tau protein that are a primary biomarker of Alzheimer's disease. They are also found in other diseases called tauopathies and disrupt neuronal communication.
Describe cortical basal ganglionic degen: Corticobasal ganglionic degeneration, also known as CBD, is a rare neurodegenerative disease characterized by progressive loss of brain tissue, particularly in the cerebral cortex and basal ganglia. It is characterized by movement disorders such as rigidity, dystonia, and apraxia, as well as cognitive impairments. The disease usually begins in people aged 50 to 70 and has a typical survival period of about eight years.
What are the symptoms of CBGD??: The symptoms of CBGD (Corticobasal Ganglionic Degeneration) include balance problems, muscle spasms, difficulty swallowing, memory problems, and cognitive impairment.
What is dysarthia?: Dysarthia is a speech disorder characterized by slurred or slow speech due to problems with the muscles used for speech production.
What are the pathologies of CBGD ?: Corticobasal Ganglionic Degeneration (CBGD) is characterized by argyrophilic thread pathology from oligodendroglial cell processes and occasional astrocytic plaques.
What are the different disorders in moto: Motor neuron diseases (MNDs) are a group of neurodegenerative disorders that affect motor neurons. The most common form of MND is amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), which causes muscle weakness and eventually paralysis. There are several other types of MNDs, such as motor neuron disease with spasticity, motor neuron disease with spasticity, motor neuron disease with spasticity, motor neuron disease with spasticity, motor neuron disease with spasticity, and motor neuron disease with spasticity.
Describe ALS: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that affects motor neurons in the brain and spinal cord. It is characterized by the degeneration and death of motor neurons, leading to muscle weakness and wasting over time. ALS affects voluntary muscles, affecting movement, speech, and breathing. There is currently no cure for ALS.
What are the symptoms on motor neurons d: The symptoms of motor neuron disease (MND) include muscle weakness, slurred speech, and swallowing difficulties. As the disease progresses, other symptoms may include increased deep tendon reflexes, muscle atrophy, and fasciculations (spontaneous muscle contractions).
What is ALS-PDC?: ALS-PDC, or Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis-Parkinsonism-Dementia Complex, is a rare neurodegenerative disorder that combines symptoms of ALS (muscle weakness and wasting) with Parkinson's disease (slowed movements) and dementia (intellectual decline). It is primarily found in specific populations, such as the Chamorro people of Guam, and is believed to be caused by environmental factors rather than genetic mutations.
What is picks disease ?: Pick's disease is a type of frontotemporal dementia that affects people under the age of 65. It causes a progressive decline in cognitive abilities such as language comprehension, reasoning, and problem-solving.
What are the symptoms of picks disease ?: The symptoms of Pick's disease include personality changes, a decline in basic functioning, and cognitive impairments such as difficulty with reasoning, problem-solving, and memory.
What are the pathologies of picks diseas: Pick's disease is characterized by frontotemporal degeneration and the presence of tau-immunopositive intracellular inclusions known as Pick bodies. It affects the frontal and/or anterolateral temporal lobes of the brain and is a type of frontotemporal dementia (FTD).
What is the cause of picks disease ?: Pick's disease is a type of frontotemporal dementia, which is caused by the progressive degeneration of brain cells in the frontal and temporal lobes. The exact cause of Pick's disease is not known, but it is believed to be a combination of genetic and environmental factors.
Describe Alzheimer\u2019s disease: Alzheimer's disease is the most common cause of dementia, characterized by a gradual decline in memory, thinking, behavior, and social skills. It progresses in stages, with symptoms increasing over time. There is currently no cure for Alzheimer's disease, but there are treatments that can slow down the progression of the disease.
What are the pathologies of ad ?: The pathologies of Alzheimer's disease (AD) include the formation of extracellular amyloid-beta (A) plaques and intracellular neurofibrillary tangles made of hyperphosphorylated tau protein.
What are the plaques in ad ?: The plaques in Alzheimer's disease (AD) are primarily composed of beta-amyloid peptide (A) and are a pathological hallmark of the disease.
What are neurofibrillary tangles in ad ?: Neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs) are intracellular aggregates of hyperphosphorylated tau protein that are a primary pathological hallmark of Alzheimer's disease.
What neurons are lost in ad ?: In Alzheimer's disease (AD), several types of neurons are lost, including pyramidal, inter-, and cholinergic neurons. The loss of cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert (NbM) occurs early in the course of the disease.
What are the earliest symptoms of ad ?: The earliest symptoms of Alzheimer's disease (AD) include memory problems, such as difficulty remembering recent events or conversations. Other early symptoms may include difficulty paying attention, problems with visual information processing, and changes in mood or behavior.
What are the later symptoms of ad ?: In the later stages of Alzheimer's disease, symptoms may include loss of bladder and bowel control, weight loss, seizures, difficulty swallowing, and changes in speech such as groaning or moaning.
What are the latest symptoms of ad ?: The latest symptoms of ADHD include difficulty paying attention, impulsiveness, restlessness, and disorganization.
How is ad assessed ?: AD (Azure Active Directory) is assessed through various measures such as data collection, analysis, and reporting. The assessment can be done using tools such as the Azure AD Assessment Guide, which provides a comprehensive overview of the AD infrastructure and provides recommendations for improvement.
What is mild cognitive impairment ?: Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) is a mild decline in cognitive function, particularly in memory, language, or critical thinking, that is more significant than what is typically expected with aging. It can be caused by a variety of factors, including neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer's disease or Parkinson's disease, as well as reversible factors such as vitamin deficiencies, sleep disorders, or medication side effects.
What is mild ad ?: Mild Alzheimer's disease (AD) is an early stage of Alzheimer's disease characterized by memory lapses, difficulty concentrating, and changes in mood or personality. It typically lasts for about two years before progressing to moderate or severe Alzheimer's disease.
What is moderate ad ?: Moderate Alzheimer's disease (MAD) is the middle stage of Alzheimer's disease, characterized by increasing severity of symptoms that were present in the mild stage. This stage can last for years or even decades, and may include symptoms such as memory loss, difficulty with daily activities, and difficulty learning new things.
What is severe ad ?: Severe AD refers to a severe form of atopic dermatitis, which is characterized by red, swollen, and itchy patches of skin that can weep fluids and lead to skin infections.
What is very severe ad ?: Very severe ADHD refers to the extent to which symptoms of ADHD affect a person's daily functioning. It is considered severe if the symptoms of ADHD significantly interfere with daily functioning, are difficult to control, and do not respond to medication.
What are the causes of ad ?: The exact causes of Alzheimer's disease (AD) are not fully understood, but it is believed to be a combination of genetic, environmental, and lifestyle factors.
What pathway forms amyloid beta proteins: Amyloid beta proteins are formed through the proteolytic processing of amyloid precursor protein (APP) by - and -secretases.
What is the amyloid hypothesis ?: The amyloid hypothesis posits that the accumulation of amyloid beta-protein (A) in the brain is the primary cause of Alzheimer's disease. It suggests that A deposition leads to neurofibrillary tangles, cell loss, and ultimately dementia.
How do the extraocular muscles of the ey: The extraocular muscles of the eye have such fine control due to their precise innervation by the oculomotor, trochlear, and abducens nerves. These nerves transmit signals to the muscles, which in turn transmit signals to the brain, allowing for smooth and precise movements of the eye.
What does the lens do ?: The lens focuses light onto the retina, allowing us to see objects at varying distances.
What does the pupil do ?: The pupil is the opening in the center of the iris that allows light to enter the eye so it can be focused on the retina to begin the process of sight. It controls how much light is let into the eye, similar to a camera aperture, and plays a significant role in controlling the depth of focus. The size of the pupil changes in response to light intensity, constricting in bright light and dilating in low light.
What is the macula ?: The macula is a small, highly pigmented area near the center of the retina, responsible for central vision and detailed tasks such as reading and recognizing faces.
What is the fovea ?: The fovea is a small depression in the macula of the retina, located in the center of the visual field. It is responsible for sharp central vision and high-resolution detail due to its dense concentration of cone photoreceptors.
What is the optic disk ?: The optic disk, also known as the optic nerve head, is a circular area in the retina where the axons of retinal ganglion cells exit the eye. It lacks photoreceptors, making it known as the blind spot in the visual field. The optic disk is also the entry point for the retina's main artery and vein.
What is presbyopia ?: Presbyopia is an age-related condition where the eyes gradually lose the ability to focus on close objects. It is a normal part of the aging process and typically starts around age 40.
What happens when light hits the cornea: When light hits the cornea, it refracts or bends the incoming rays, allowing them to converge precisely at the retina, enabling clear vision.
What is the term to describe the lens ch: The term to describe the lens changing shape to focus light rays is accommodation.
How does the lens increase its refractiv: The lens increases its refractive power through the process of accommodation. During accommodation, the lens becomes more convex, which increases its ability to converge light rays and increase its refractive power.
What is hyperopia ?: Hyperopia, also known as farsightedness, is a vision condition where distant objects are seen clearly, but nearby objects appear blurry. It occurs when the eye focuses light behind the retina instead of on it.
What is myopia ?: Myopia, also known as nearsightedness, is an eye condition where distant objects appear blurry while close objects appear clear. This occurs when the shape of the eye causes light rays to focus in front of the retina instead of directly on it.
How is light converted into neural activ: Light is converted into neural activity by specialized cells in the retina called rods and cones. These cells contain light-sensitive pigments that change shape when they are exposed to light, causing an electrical signal to be transmitted through the optic nerve to the brain.
What are the cells in the retina involve: The cells in the retina involved in pre-processing information before sending it through the optic nerve include horizontal cells, bipolar cells, amacrine cells, and ganglion cells.
What is the difference between the bipol: Bipolar cells are projection neurons that transmit information from photoreceptors to ganglion cells. Horizontal cells, on the other hand, modulate information transfer between bipolar cells and photoreceptors, facilitating light adaptation and introducing lateral inhibition.
What are the different types of photorec: There are two main types of photoreceptors in the human retina: rods and cones. Rods are responsible for night vision and detecting movement, while cones are responsible for color vision and are divided into short-wavelength (blue), medium-wavelength (green), and long-wavelength (red) cones.
Where does absorption of light occur in: Absorption of light occurs in photoreceptors in the outer segment, where visual pigments are located. This process is crucial because it initiates phototransduction, converting light into electrical signals for visual processing. The absorbed light triggers a series of biochemical changes that lead to the hyperpolarization of the cell, starting the signal transmission to the brain.
What do rods and cones look like ?: Rods are long, narrow cells with a rod-shaped outer segment, while cones are cone-shaped cells with a cone-shaped outer segment.
Explain what happens in the signal trans: When a photon is absorbed by a photoreceptor, it triggers a signal cascade that leads to a decrease in intracellular cGMP levels. This decrease in cGMP levels affects the membrane potential of the photoreceptor, but does not stimulate an action potential. Instead, the signal is transmitted to the ganglion cells in the retina, where it is processed and interpreted.
What does scotoptic mean: Scotoptic refers to vision in low-light conditions, primarily involving the retinal rods as light receptors. It is the type of vision that occurs when the eyes are dark-adapted, allowing for perception in low-light conditions, such as at night or in dimly lit environments. The term originates from the Greek word for darkness, skotos.
What does mescopic mean ?: Mesoscopic refers to a size scale that is intermediate between microscopic and macroscopic. It describes objects or systems that are larger than a few atoms or molecules but much smaller than everyday objects.
What does photopic mean ?: Photopic refers to vision in bright light conditions, such as daylight. It is primarily mediated by the cone cells in the retina and allows for color perception and higher visual acuity compared to scotopic vision, which occurs in low light conditions.
What is the pigment in rods called and w: The pigment in rods is called rhodopsin. The three types of cones are L (long/red), M (medium/green), and S (short/blue).
How are we able to see so many different: We are able to see so many different colours because our eyes have three types of color receptors: red, blue, and green. When light enters our eyes, it activates these receptors, which then send signals to our brain, allowing us to perceive a wide range of colors.
When do we perceive white light ?: We perceive white light when all the cones in our eyes are stimulated equally, or when all the rods in our eyes are stimulated at the same time. This happens when light of all visible wavelengths is present at equal intensity.
Why is colour blindness more common in m: Color blindness is more common in men than women because the genes responsible for the most common type of color blindness, red-green color blindness, are located on the X chromosome. Males have one X chromosome, while females have two X chromosomes, so males are more likely to be affected if their single X chromosome is defective.
What is trichromatic vision ?: Trichromatic vision is the ability of humans and some other animals to see different colors, mediated by interactions among three types of color-sensing cone cells in the retina. Each type of cone cell is sensitive to a different wavelength of light, typically red, green, and blue. These cones work together to create our perception of color.
What is anomalous trichromatic vision ?: Anomalous trichromatic vision is a type of color vision deficiency where one of the three cone types (red, green, or blue) in the eye isn't functioning as expected. It is the most common form of color blindness and affects less than 0.01% of the population.
What is dichromatic vision ?: Dichromatic vision is a type of color vision where an organism has two types of photoreceptor cells, or cones, that are sensitive to different wavelengths of light. This allows for a limited range of color perception compared to trichromatic vision, which involves three types of cones.
What is the receptive field ?: The receptive field refers to the region in the input space that a particular layer of a convolutional neural network (CNN) is trained on. In the context of visual perception, it refers to the area of the input space that a particular layer of a CNN is trained on.
What is the receptive field centre and r: The receptive field centre is a region in the visual field where light stimuli evoke a positive response in a ganglion cell. The receptive field surround is the area around the center, which has an opposing effect on the cell's response due to indirect communication among retinal neurons. This surround-centre structure enhances sensitivity to edges in visual scenes and promotes efficient representation of natural stimuli.
What does the RF centre and RF surround: The RF center and RF surround make direct contact to the retina.
What happens with on-centre bipolar cell: When there is light in the centre of an ON-center bipolar cell's receptive field, it depolarizes and becomes more active. This leads to an increase in the firing rate of the associated ON-center ganglion cells.
What are the 3 types of ganglion cells ?: The three most common types of ganglion cells are parasol cells, midget cells, and small bistratified cells.
What is the distribution of ganglion cel: The distribution of ganglion cells in the retina varies depending on the type of ganglion cell. In most cases, ganglion cells are located near the inner limiting membrane adjacent to the vitreous. However, in some cases, ganglion cells can be found among amacrine cells in the inner nuclear layer.
What do on centre ganglion cells and off: In the light, ON-center ganglion cells increase their firing rate, while OFF-center ganglion cells decrease their firing rate. In the dark, OFF-center ganglion cells decrease their firing rate, while ON-center ganglion cells increase their firing rate.
What happens to off centre bipolar cells: When there is light in the center of an off-centre bipolar cell, it will become hyperpolarized. This is because the light reduces the release of glutamate from photoreceptors, which is excitatory for off-centre bipolar cells.
What happens to on centre bipolar cells: When the centre is in the dark, ON bipolar cells become hyperpolarized. This means they become more negatively charged and are less likely to transmit electrical signals. In contrast, when the centre is in the dark, OFF bipolar cells become more positively charged and are more likely to transmit electrical signals.
What happens to off centre bipolar cells: When the center is dark, off-center bipolar cells and ganglion cells become depolarized. This is because when the center is dark, the OFF-center bipolar cells and OFF-center ganglion cells are depolarized, while the ON-center bipolar cells and ON-center ganglion cells are hyperpolarized. This means that when the center is dark, the OFF-center bipolar cells and OFF-center ganglion cells are more active than the ON-center bipolar cells and ganglion cells.
How many inputs from photoreceptors do b: The number of inputs from photoreceptors that bipolar cells receive varies depending on their location in the retina. In the fovea, each bipolar cell receives input from only one photoreceptor, while in the periphery, each bipolar cell receives input from multiple photoreceptors.
What is the visual system specialised to: The visual system is specialized to detect and process light within the visible spectrum. It can detect and process colors, shapes, motion, and other visual stimuli.
What do horizontal cells do ?: Horizontal cells are interneurons in the retina that integrate and regulate input from multiple photoreceptor cells. They are responsible for increasing contrast through lateral inhibition and adapting to both bright and dim light conditions.
What are the colour opponencies you can: Complementary opponencies are blue and orange, red and green, yellow and purple. Mid-level opponencies are bluish violet versus lime, teal versus orange, and blueish green versus yellow.
What is colour perception based on ?: Color perception is based on the electromagnetic spectrum, specifically the light absorption, reflection, emission spectra of an object. The human eye has cone photoreceptors sensitive to varying wavelengths of light, enabling contrast and separation of a spectrum of colors. This information is then relayed to the visual cortex for processing, leading to the subjective experience of color.
Which side of the brain is the left visu: The left visual field is processed on the right side of the brain due to the contralateral nature of visual processing. This means that information from the left side of the visual field is collected from both eyes and sent to the right hemisphere of the brain.
What is the human visual pathway ?: The human visual pathway consists of the retina, optic nerve, optic chiasm, optic tracts, lateral geniculate bodies, optic radiations, and the visual cortex. It transmits visual information from the retina to the brain via the optic nerve, optic chiasm, optic tracts, lateral geniculate bodies, and optic radiations.
What is the full visual field, left/righ: The full visual field is the entire area that can be seen while looking straight ahead, including both eyes' inputs. It can be divided into left and right hemifields, which split the visual field into two equal regions from the center to the periphery. The binocular visual field is the overlapping area of both eyes' visual fields, allowing for depth perception and a wider central view.
At the optic chiasm which fibres cross ?: At the optic chiasm, fibers from the nasal (medial) half of each retina cross over to the contralateral optic tract. Fibers from the temporal (lateral) halves remain on the same side.
What are perceptual disparities perceive: Perceptual disparities are perceived as depth by the brain. This is known as stereopsis, where the brain uses binocular disparities to compute the relative and absolute depths of objects in space.
What is the retinofugal projection ?: The retinofugal projection is one of the major projection paths of the retinal ganglion cells, primarily directing visual information to the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus and then to the primary visual cortex.
What does the lateral geniculate nucleus: The lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) is a small, ovoid structure located in the thalamus. It is a ventral projection of the thalamus and is responsible for processing visual information. It has six principal layers of cells, with the largest cells forming the deepest two (magnocellular) layers.
What does it mean by retinotopic project: Retinotopic projections refer to the mapping of visual input from the retina to specific neurons in the visual cortex, where neighboring points in the visual field correspond to neighboring points on the cortex. This allows for a structured representation of the visual field in the brain, facilitating visual processing.
What is the cytoarchitecture of the visu: The cytoarchitecture of the visual cortex is characterized by a dense network of neurons and glial cells. The primary visual cortex (V1) is particularly densely populated with neurons and glial cells, while the secondary visual cortex (V2) is more sparsely populated with neurons and glial cells.
What are the cells like in the visual co: The visual cortex is composed of various types of cells, including pyramidal cells, spiny stellate cells, and occipital cells. Each cell in the visual cortex has a receptive field, which is a specific area in space where a stimulus will cause activation. These cells are organized into columns and modules, which are responsible for processing and interpreting visual information.
Where do layers 2,3 and 4b project?: Layers 2, 3, and 4B project mainly to other cortical regions, such as V2. They also project to the next higher cortical area, which is V2.
Where does layer 5 project to ?: Layer 5 of the neocortex projects to various areas of the brain, including the thalamus, striatum, and brainstem.
Where does layer 6 project to ?: Layer 6, also known as the presentation layer, projects to the application layer for processing or display of formatted data.
Why is the primary visual cortex also ca: The primary visual cortex is also called the striate cortex because it has a distinctive white stripe, known as the stria of Gennari, which is visible to the naked eye. The term'striate' means'striped'.
What layers do the K type ganglion cells: K type ganglion cells, also known as koniocellular cells, terminate in the visual cortex in layers 4C and 4A.
Which layer of the primary visual cortex: Information from both eyes from magnocellular pathways combines in the primary visual cortex (V1).
The information from both eyes is combined from parvocellular inputs in layer IVC of the primary visual cortex (V1).
What is ocular dominance ?: Ocular dominance, also known as eye dominance, is the tendency of one eye to prefer visual input over the other when both eyes are open. It is similar to being right- or left-handed, but the dominant eye may not always be on the same side as the dominant hand. The dominant eye typically communicates better with the brain's visual cortex.
What does ocular dominance create?: Ocular dominance is a phenomenon where the brain responds more strongly to input from one eye than the other. This leads to a preference for the input from the dominant eye, resulting in a person having a dominant eye.
What information from the retina is proc: Information from the left visual hemifield is processed at the right lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN), while information from the right visual hemifield is processed at the left LGN.
Why are layers 2 and 3 of V1 very import: Layers 2 and 3 of V1 are very important because they play a crucial role in the integration of visual information and feedback from downstream cortical areas. These layers are involved in the perception of simple visual components such as orientation and direction, as well as the processing of complex visual stimuli such as color and motion.
What did staining with cytochrome oxidas: Staining with cytochrome oxidase in the cortex reveals a regular pattern of darkly stained patches, particularly in the upper layers of the primate primary visual cortex. This staining method has been used to study the cytoarchitecture of the brain and has shown important functional subdivisions in the macaque visual cortex.
What were the pillars rich in cytochrome: The pillars rich in cytochrome oxidase in the visual cortex are also known as blobs or puffs. These structures are most prominent in layers II and III, but also present in layers V and VI. They are thought to contain unoriented, color-opponent neurons.
What do the receptive fields of blobs di: The receptive fields of blobs in the visual cortex display concentric receptive fields that are insensitive to orientation. They are specialized for color vision, particularly for red-green and blue-yellow colors.
What organisation do neurons display whe: Neurons in V1 display a columnar architecture when an electrode is advanced vertically. This means that neurons with similar response properties, such as the same orientation preference, are located nearby one another.
What organisation do neurons display in: When an electrode is advanced obliquely through the cortex, neurons display a columnar organization. This organization is known as ocular dominance columns, and it reflects the preferential activation of neurons based on input from either the ipsi- or contralateral eye.
Describe the parallel magnocellular path: The parallel magnocellular pathway is a subcortical pathway that carries information about large, fast-moving objects and is colorblind. It is specialized for detecting contrast sensitivity and coarse features, and its information is processed through the "where" pathway to the parieto-occipital cortex, where it is involved in spatial awareness and motion perception.
Describe the parallel parvocellular path: The parallel parvocellular pathway in the cortex is one of the two main pathways from the retina to the visual cortex. It is primarily responsible for processing color and fine detail information. It originates in the retina and projects through the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) of the thalamus to the visual cortex. If this pathway is damaged, it can lead to problems with color and fine detail recognition.
Describe the parallel pathway for blobs: The parallel pathway for blobs in the cortex involves the convergence of inputs from the parvocellular and koniocellular layers of the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) onto the blobs in layer 2/3 of the striate cortex. The blobs are specifically associated with color sensitivity, receiving direct input from the koniocellular layers of the LGN. This pathway allows for the mixing of visual signals, contributing to the processing of color and other visual information.
What do the cells in the visual cortex h: The cells in the visual cortex respond to visual stimuli within their receptive fields, which are specific areas in space relative to the fovea. They are particularly tuned to respond optimally to lines at specific orientations. Additionally, some cells respond preferentially to movement in certain directions.

What does intensity of sound refer to ?: The intensity of sound refers to the amount of sound energy passing through a unit area per unit time, essentially indicating the loudness of a sound. It is measured in units such as Watts per square meter (W/m2) and is often expressed in decibels (dB).
What is sound ?: Sound is a longitudinal wave that travels through a medium such as air or water. It is characterized by its amplitude (loudness) and frequency (pitch). Sound can be perceived by the human ear and can also exist outside the range of human hearing.
What does the frequency of sound refer t: The frequency of sound refers to the number of sound waves that pass a fixed point in one second, measured in hertz (Hz). It primarily determines the pitch of the sound, with higher frequencies corresponding to higher pitches and lower frequencies corresponding to lower pitches. The human hearing range typically spans from 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz.
What does the middle ear do ?: The middle ear carries sound waves from the outer ear to the inner ear, where they are processed and sent to the brain. It also regulates air pressure through the Eustachian tube.
What are the ossicles of the Middle ear: The ossicles of the middle ear are the malleus, incus, and stapes. They are also known as the hammer, anvil, and stirrup. They transmit sound vibrations from the eardrum to the inner ear.
What is the attenuation reflex ?: The attenuation reflex, also known as the stapedius reflex, is an involuntary muscle contraction in the middle ear that occurs in response to loud sounds. It helps protect the inner ear from damage by reducing the amount of sound that reaches it.
What is conductive hearing loss ?: Conductive hearing loss is a type of hearing loss that occurs when there is damage or obstruction in the outer or middle ear, preventing sound waves from reaching the inner ear. This can be caused by damage to the ear canal, ear drum, or middle ear bones.
What is a major part of the outer ear ?: A major part of the outer ear is the auricle, also known as the pinna. It is the visible part of the ear and is made up of cartilage and skin. Other parts of the outer ear include the tragus, helix, and lobule.
What is the inner ear like ?: The inner ear is the innermost part of the ear, responsible for both hearing and balance. It consists of the cochlea, which is shaped like a snail and converts sound vibrations into electrical signals, and the semicircular canals, which help with balance and spatial orientation.
How does the basilar membrane move ?: The basilar membrane moves as a traveling wave of deformation when a sound wave is transmitted to the fluid of the inner ear. This movement varies along its length due to differences in stiffness and width, with the base vibrating earlier than the apex. This movement stimulates the inner hair cells attached to the membrane, facilitating auditory transduction.
How are different frequency sounds heard: Different frequency sounds are heard by the human ear, which can detect a wide range of frequencies from 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz. This range includes low-frequency sounds such as rumbles and low-pitched noises, as well as high-frequency sounds such as squeals and whistles.
What is the organ of corti ?: The organ of Corti is the receptor organ for hearing located in the cochlea of the inner ear. It is composed of sensory cells called hair cells and supporting structures that sit on a flexible basilar membrane.
What does the round windows do ?: The round windows is a membrane-covered opening in the cochlea of the inner ear that facilitates the movement of fluids in response to sound vibrations, aiding in the process of hearing.
What is the helicotrema ?: The helicotrema is an opening at the apex of the cochlea, where the scala tympani and scala vestibuli meet. It allows fluid communication between these two compartments of the cochlea.
Where are high frequency sounds heard on: High frequency sounds are heard on the basilar membrane near the base of the cochlea.
Where are low frequency sounds heard on: Low frequency sounds are heard on the basilar membrane near the apex.
What is the purpose of the tonotopoc org: The purpose of the tonotopic organization of the basilar membrane is to map specific sound frequencies to specific locations along the membrane, allowing for the systematic processing of auditory information by frequency as it is transmitted to the brain. This arrangement allows high-frequency sounds to stimulate the base of the cochlea, while low-frequency sounds to stimulate the apex.
What happens is the main purpose of the: The main purpose of auditory receptors (hair cells) is to detect sound vibrations and convert them into electrical signals through a process called mechanotransduction. This process allows the brain to perceive sound.
What are the types of hair cells ?: There are two main types of hair cells in the cochlea: inner and outer hair cells. Inner hair cells are the primary sensory receptors, while outer hair cells are the efferent axons that transmit sound to the brain.
What structures are linked to the basila: The structures linked to the basilar membrane to form a structural unit are the sensory hair cells, which are located in an epithelial ridge anchored on the basilar membrane.
What happens when the basilar membrane m: When the basilar membrane moves downwards, it causes the tectorial membrane to shear the tips of the stereocilia towards the modiolus. This causes an inhibitory response in the hair cell, causing it to hyperpolarize or enter a refractory phase.

When the basilar membrane moves upward, it responds to incoming sound waves, creating a traveling wave of deformation. This movement helps identify the profile of the sound by acting like a series of band-pass filters.
What makes the hair cells rigid ?: The rigidity of hair cells is primarily due to the overlapping scale-like cells that make up the outermost layer of the hair shaft, called the cuticle. These cells are surrounded by a protective layer of keratin, which also contributes to the rigidity of the hair shaft.
What are the concentration of ions in th: The endolymph has a high concentration of potassium ions (140 mEq/L) and a low concentration of sodium ions (15 mEq/L).
What is the concentration of ions in the: The concentration of ions in the perilymph is similar to that of plasma and cerebrospinal fluid. The concentration of sodium ions is approximately 138-150 mM, while the concentration of potassium ions is approximately 4-6.9 mM, and the concentration of chloride ions is approximately 130 mM.
How much more positive is the endolymph,: The endolymph is approximately 80-90 mV more positive than the perilymph due to the higher concentration of potassium ions in the endolymph compared to sodium ions in the perilymph.
What happens when potassium channels on: When potassium channels on hair cells open, it leads to a decrease in the cell's membrane potential. This decrease in membrane potential is known as hyperpolarization. This hyperpolarization can lead to a variety of physiological responses, including changes in cell growth and differentiation.
What are the potassium channels like in: The potassium channels in the stereocilia are called mechanotransduction channels. They open in response to the deflection of the stereocilia, allowing potassium ions to enter the hair cell. This process is crucial for converting mechanical sound vibrations into electrical signals that travel to the brain.
What is the kinacillium ?: A kinocilium is a specialized cilium found on the apex of hair cells in the sensory epithelium of the vertebrate inner ear. It plays a crucial role in the development and arrangement of stereocilia, with only one kinocilium present per hair cell.
What happens when the stereocillia move: When the stereocillia move towards the kinacillium, the hair cells depolarize and release more glutamate, stimulating the neurons of the vestibular nerve. This stimulates the vestibular system and helps maintain balance and orientation.

When the stereocilia move away from the kinacillium, the tension on the tip-link filaments decreases. This decreases the opening of non-specific ion channels, allowing more ions to enter the hair cell. This decrease in ion flow can lead to changes in hearing and balance.
How many spiral ganglion cells does a si: A single inner hair cell synapses onto as many as 20 or more spiral ganglion cells.
What is the purpose of the outer hair ce: The outer hair cells act as a cochlear amplifier, enhancing the sensitivity and frequency selectivity of mechanical vibrations in the cochlea. They help improve sound detection and localization at higher frequencies, which are often dampened by cochlear fluid. This amplification is crucial for improving sound detection and localization.
What happens in sensorineural hearing lo: Sensorineural hearing loss occurs due to damage to the inner ear or the nerves that transmit sound signals to the brain. This can cause difficulty hearing soft sounds and even louder sounds to sound unclear or muffled. It is the most common type of hearing loss and is usually permanent.
What is the treatment for sensorineural: The treatment for sensorineural hearing loss varies depending on the underlying cause. In some cases, medications like corticosteroids can be used to reduce swelling in the cochlea, while in others, surgery may be necessary. It is important to consult with a healthcare professional for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan.
How are frequencies below 200Hz encoded: Frequencies below 200Hz are encoded by the auditory system through place coding. This means that the location of the sound wave on the basilar membrane corresponds to a specific frequency. The rate at which these hair cells fire also encodes information about the sound's amplitude and other characteristics.
Where is tonotopy seen for sound frequen: Tonotopy for sound frequencies greater than 200Hz is seen throughout the auditory system, including the cochlea, subcortical regions, and the cortex.
What is phase locking ?: Phase locking refers to the consistent alignment of phase values across different signals or components, indicating a nonrandom phase distribution. It is often used in contexts like phase synchronization, where the phase of one signal is maintained relative to another. Additionally, phase-locked loops (PLLs) are control systems that generate an output signal with a fixed phase relative to an input signal, ensuring frequency consistency.
When does neuronal firing= frequency ?: Neuronal firing rate is the rate at which a neuron discharges short-duration electrical pulses called spikes, measured in spikes per second (sp/s) or hertz (Hz).
When does group firing rate= frequency ?: Group firing rate is equal to frequency when it is measured as the number of spikes per second (sp/s) or hertz (Hz).
What is the ascending auditory pathway ?: The ascending auditory pathway is the pathway that transmits sound information from the cochlea to the brain. It includes the cochlear nucleus, superior olivary complex, inferior colliculus, and medial geniculate nucleus before reaching the auditory cortex.
Where does decussation occur in the asce: Decussation occurs in the ascending auditory pathway at multiple levels, including the superior colliculus commissure, the trapezoid body, and the superior colliculus nucleus.
What is the function of the inferior col: The inferior colliculus serves as a relay point for auditory information, processing and integrating input from the inner ear to the auditory cortex. It plays a crucial role in sound perception, including locating sounds in space and processing complex auditory patterns.
What are the 2 mechanisms for encoding s: The two mechanisms for encoding sound localisation are binaural cues and the place code.
What are the 2 mechanisms for horizOntal: The two mechanisms for horizontal sound localisation are interaural time differences (ITD) and interaural level differences (ILD).
What is interaural time difference ?: Interaural time difference (ITD) is the time interval between when a sound reaches one ear and when it reaches the other ear. It is a cue used by the auditory system to determine the direction of a sound source.

What is interaural intensity difference: Interaural intensity difference (IID) refers to the difference in amplitude of a sound as it reaches each ear. This difference occurs because the head attenuates the sound wave, causing a sound coming from one side to be louder at the ear closer to the source. This phenomenon is particularly effective for localizing high-frequency sounds and diminishes as the sound source moves further to the side of the head.
Why is serotonin called serotonin ?: Serotonin is called serotonin because it is derived from the Greek words'serum' and 'tonin', which refer to its ability to cause vasoconstriction in vascular smooth muscle.
What groups make up serotonin ?: Serotonin, also known as 5-hydroxytryptamine (5-HT), is primarily derived from the amino acid tryptophan. It is synthesized through the hydroxylation and decarboxylation processes, which involve enzymes such as tryptophan hydroxylase and tryptophan decarboxylase.
Where is serotonin present ?: Serotonin is primarily present in the brain, where it is synthesized in the raphe nuclei, and in the gastrointestinal tract, where it is produced by enterochromaffin cells.
What amino acid can be converted into se: The amino acid that can be converted into serotonin is tryptophan. We can get tryptophan through dietary sources such as meat, poultry, fish, dairy, nuts, and seeds. Once absorbed, tryptophan is converted into serotonin through an enzymatic reaction involving tryptophan hydroxylase and aromatic-L-amino-acid decarboxylase.
What is eosinophilia myalgia ?: Eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome (EMS) is a rare disorder characterized by an increase in eosinophils, a type of white blood cell, in the body. This can lead to inflammation in various organ systems, including the muscles, skin, and lungs. Symptoms may include muscle pain, fatigue, skin rashes, and joint pain.
How is serotonin made ?: Serotonin is made from the amino acid tryptophan through a two-step process. First, tryptophan is hydroxylated to form 5-hydroxytryptophan, which is then decarboxylated to produce serotonin. This process occurs primarily in the raphe nuclei of the brain and enterochromaffin cells of the intestinal mucosa.
How is serotonin stored ?: Serotonin is stored in vesicles within the presynaptic neuron until it is released into the synaptic cleft. After release, any remaining serotonin can be taken back up into the presynaptic neuron by the serotonin transporter (SERT).
After the release of serotonin what happ: After the release of serotonin, it can either bind to serotonin receptors on the postsynaptic neuron, degraded by monoamine oxidase, or taken back up into the presynaptic neuron by the serotonin transporter (SERT).
What is the effect of P-chloroamphetamin: P-chloroamphetamine (PCA) and fenfluramine both produce long-lasting decreases in serotonin transporter (SERT) binding and tissue levels of serotonin. These effects are mediated by the serotonin transporter, although they may not share the same binding site.
What effect do SSRIs have on the uptake: SSRIs (serotonin selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors) block the serotonin uptake transporter (SERT) in the brain, resulting in increased levels of serotonin and antidepressant effects.
What is fenfluramine used for and why ?: Fenfluramine is used to treat seizures associated with Dravet syndrome and Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. It works by increasing serotonin levels, which helps to control neurotransmission and reduce seizures. It was previously used as an appetite suppressant but was discontinued due to cardiovascular toxicity.
What does ecstasy do to the body ?: Ecstasy can cause a range of physical effects on the body, including increased heart rate, high blood pressure, and dehydration. It can also affect the brain chemistry by boosting serotonin levels and causing euphoria. In high doses, ecstasy can lead to severe side effects such as hyperthermia, kidney failure, and even death.
How is serotonin metabolised ?: Serotonin is primarily metabolized through the action of monoamine oxidase (MAO), which converts it into 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA). This process occurs mainly in the liver and kidneys, where it is excreted in urine.
Is MAO-A or MAO-B more effective at meta: MAO-A is more effective at metabolizing serotonin and is present in serotonergic neurons.
What are examples of serotonin neurotoxi: Examples of serotonin neurotoxins include 5,7-dihydroxytryptamine (5,7-DHT) and 2'-NH2-MPTP.
What is the purpose of amphetamines in t: Amphetamines increase the levels of dopamine and norepinephrine in the brain, but they also increase the levels of serotonin to a lesser extent. This can lead to increased feelings of euphoria, motivation, and alertness.
What are the 2 main ascending serotonerg: The two main ascending serotonergic pathways from the midbrain raphe nuclei are the dorsal periventricular pathway and the ventral tegmental radiations.
Explain the dorsal paraventricular pathw: The dorsal paraventricular pathway (PVT) is a pathway that connects the hypothalamus with rostral regions such as the septal nuclei and brainstem areas such as the ventral tegmental area and reticular formation. It plays a crucial role in regulating arousal, motivation, and behavior, integrating information about internal states with emotional contexts and regulating arousal, motivation, and behavior.
Explain the ventral tegmental pathway ?: The ventral tegmental pathway (VTA) is a dopaminergic pathway that connects the ventral tegmental area (VTA) in the midbrain to the ventral striatum in the forebrain. This pathway releases dopamine, which plays a crucial role in regulating mood, motivation, and cognition.
Where do the 2 ascending pathways join ?: The two ascending pathways, the dorsal column system and the spinothalamic tract, join in the thalamus of the brain.
What are the 3 important descending sero: The three important descending serotonergic pathways to the spinal cord are the ACC-PAG-RVM pathway, the descending raphe serotonergic pathway, and the amygdala serotonergic pathway.
What effect does serotonin have at recep: Serotonin has a variety of effects at its receptors, including modulation of mood, appetite, and sleep. It binds to serotonin receptors, which are then activated by serotonin ligands such as 5-HT1A and 5-HT2A. Activation of serotonin receptors can lead to various physiological and neuropsychological effects.
What type of receptor is 5-HT3 ?: The 5-HT3 receptor is a cation-selective ion channel that belongs to the Cys-loop superfamily of ligand-gated ion channels.
Describe 5-HT 1 receptors ?: 5-HT 1 receptors are a subfamily of serotonin receptors that bind to serotonin. They are G protein-coupled receptors, consisting of five subtypes: 5-HT 1A, 5-HT 1B, 5-HT 1C, and 5-HT 1D. These receptors are primarily found in the brain and other tissues, with the 5-HT 1A receptor being the most widespread in the central nervous system.
Explain the 5-HT 1 somatodendritic autor: 5-HT 1 somatodendritic autoreceptors are located on the soma and dendrites of serotonin (5-HT) neurons, particularly in the raphe nucleus. They play a crucial role in controlling serotonin release by exerting a negative feedback influence on neuronal firing. This means that when activated, they reduce the amount of serotonin released, thereby limiting further release. This mechanism helps regulate serotonin levels throughout the brain.
What is the function of busprione?: Buspirone is an anxiolytic medication primarily used to treat anxiety disorders, particularly generalized anxiety disorder (GAD). It works by increasing action at serotonin receptors in the brain as a serotonin 5-HT 1A receptor partial agonist.
What is the function of lysergic acid di: Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) is a potent psychedelic drug that intensifies thoughts, emotions, and sensory perception. It can induce mystical, spiritual, or religious experiences at lower doses, and primarily inducing visual effects at higher doses.
What is LSd?: LSD is a synthetic psychedelic drug that alters perception, mood, and thought, often causing hallucinations and mystical experiences.
Explain the 5-HT1 presynaptic autorecept: The 5-HT1 presynaptic autoreceptors are located on the dendrites and cell bodies of serotonin neurons in the raphe nuclei. When serotonin binds to these receptors, it triggers a signaling cascade that opens potassium channels and inhibits adenylyl cyclase, resulting in a reduction in neuronal firing and serotonin release. This autoreceptor-mediated inhibition is thought to play a role in the therapeutic effects of serotonergic antidepressants
What is sumatriptan ?: Sumatriptan is a medication used to treat migraine and cluster headaches. It belongs to a class of drugs called selective serotonin receptor agonists or triptans. It works by narrowing blood vessels in the head and blocking pain signals from reaching the brain.
How does sumatriptan relieve migraines a: Sumatriptan relieves migraines by narrowing blood vessels in the head and stopping pain signals from reaching the brain. Other drugs also used for migraine relief include rizatriptan, zolmitriptan, and amitriptyline.
Describe 5-HT 3 receptors: The 5-HT3 receptor is a cation-selective ligand-gated ion channel that belongs to the Cys-loop superfamily of ligand-gated ion channels. It has five subunits, each comprising an extracellular N-terminal domain for ligand binding, a transmembrane domain with four interconnected alpha helices, and a large cytoplasmic tail. These receptors mediate neuronal depolarization and excitation in the central and peripheral nervous systems.
What is ondansetron ?: Ondansetron, also known as Zofran, is a medication used to prevent nausea and vomiting caused by cancer treatments, surgeries, or pregnancy. It belongs to a class of drugs called serotonin 5-HT3 receptor antagonists.
What are the links with serotonin and hu: Serotonin is a neurotransmitter that plays a crucial role in regulating appetite and mood. When serotonin levels are low, the body produces more hunger hormones, such as leptin and ghrelin. When serotonin levels are high, the body produces more satiety hormones, such as norepinephrine and epinephrine, which promote feelings of satiety and reduce hunger.
What are the links between serotonin and: Serotonin is a neurotransmitter that plays a role in regulating emotions and behavior, including aggression. Studies have shown that serotonin deficiency is associated with increased aggression in children and adolescents. However, the relationship between serotonin and aggression is complex and multifaceted, and more research is needed to fully understand it.
What is teh predatory aggression pathway: The predatory aggression pathway refers to the neural circuitry underlying quiet, targeted attacks observed in animals like cats killing prey, and is also recognized in humans, particularly in psychopaths who view others as inferior prey. This form of aggression is characterized by a calculated and stealthy approach, contrasting with reactive or defensive aggression.
What is the affective aggression pathway: The affective aggression pathway refers to impulsive or reactive aggression that occurs in response to strong emotions such as anger, fear, or anxiety. It is characterized by a lack of premeditation and is often triggered by perceived threats.
What are the links between serotonin and: Serotonin is a neurotransmitter that plays a crucial role in mood regulation. Low levels of serotonin have been linked to depression, anxiety, and OCD. Serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are commonly used to treat depression by increasing serotonin levels.
What is the link between serotonin and s: Serotonin is a neurotransmitter that plays a crucial role in regulating the sleep-wake cycle. It is primarily produced in the hypothalamus and hypothalamus-pituitary-adrenal axis (HPA-axis). Serotonin levels are higher during sleep and lower during wakefulness, and disruptions in serotonin levels can lead to sleep disturbances such as insomnia.
Where is serotonin present in the GIT ?: Serotonin is primarily present in the enterochromaffin cells of the gastrointestinal mucosa and within neurons of the enteric nervous system.
Why is it important to have sufficient t: Having sufficient tryptophan in your diet is important because it plays a crucial role in the production of serotonin and melatonin, which are important for mood regulation and sleep quality. A deficiency in tryptophan can lead to anxiety, depression, and insomnia.
What is the link between serotonin and n: Serotonin plays a crucial role in regulating neuroendocrine function, particularly in the gut. Serotonin is produced by neuroendocrine cells in the gut and plays a role in regulating food intake and movement. Additionally, serotonin synthesis is dependent on tryptophan, which is also produced by neuroendocrine cells in the gut.
What is the link between serotonin and c: The link between serotonin and circadian rhythm is that serotonin is a neurotransmitter that plays a crucial role in regulating the circadian rhythm. Serotonin levels are regulated by the circadian clock, which is a network of circadian hormones and neurotransmitters that control sleep and wakefulness. Serotonin levels can be disrupted by a variety of factors, including stress, anxiety, and sleep deprivation.
Describe the structure of neuropeptides: Neuropeptides are small protein-like molecules that function as neurotransmitters and modulators in the nervous system. They are synthesized from precursor proteins through post-translational processing and are released from dense core vesicles. The structure of neuropeptides varies depending on the type of peptide and its function. Some neuropeptides are short, while others are long and complex.
What are the different families of neuro: There are several families of neuropeptides, including the opioids, cholecystokinin/gastrin, and galanin-like peptides. The opioids family includes -endorphin, enkephalins, and dynorphins, while the cholecystokinin/gastrin family includes -melanocyte-stimulating hormone ( -MSH) and galanin-like peptide.
What is the benefit of neuropeptides inc: Neuropeptides, including the sequences of other neuropeptides, benefit the body by modulating a wide range of bodily functions and influencing sensory perception. They play a crucial role in both peripheral and central nervous system activities, potentially contributing to conditions such as migraines and Alzheimer's disease. Additionally, their evolutionary conservation suggests that they may have important, yet undiscovered, roles in health and disease.
How are neuropeptides synthesised ?: Neuropeptides are synthesized in the neuronal cell body as large precursor proteins, which are then sequestered into the endoplasmic reticulum. These precursors then undergo cleavage and posttranslational processing to yield multiple bioactive peptides. This process is tissue-specific and can involve RNA editing, resulting in variations in the final peptide products.
What is another name for synaptic vesicl: Another name for synaptic vesicles containing neuropeptides is neurosecretory vesicles.
What happens to neuropeptides after ther: Neuropeptides are slowly removed from the extracellular space and eventually degraded by the body. This process breaks down neuropeptides into amino acids that can be recycled by the body.
What factor helps to increase the divers: Tissue-specific cleavage of pro-peptides helps to increase the diversity of neuropeptides by generating distinct populations of mature peptides from a single pro-peptide.
What enzyme converts the prepropeptide i: The enzyme that converts the prepropeptide into the propeptide varies depending on the specific context. However, some common enzymes involved in this process include signal peptidases, peptidases, and peptidases-like enzymes.
What effect does cleaving the propeptide: Cleaving the propeptide in the vesicle allows for the maturation and activation of the protein, making it more biologically active and able to perform its intended function.
What is the difference about the release: The main difference between the release of small molecule neurotransmitters and neuropeptides is that neuropeptides are synthesized in the cell body and transported to the axon terminal, while small molecule neurotransmitters are synthesized in the presynaptic terminal and transported to the axon terminal.
What does it mean by some neuropeptides: Some neuropeptides can be released extrasynaptically, which means they are released outside of synaptic structures. This type of release allows neuropeptides to diffuse throughout the nervous system and affect multiple neurons at once.
When small molecule neurotransmitters an: When small molecule neurotransmitters and peptides are colocalised, they cause conjoint ionotropic ('classical') and metabotropic ('modulatory') actions. This co-transmission leads to effects that are qualitatively different from those caused by small-molecule transmitters alone. Neuropeptides can act as both transmitters and trophic factors, often playing a role in response to challenges like injury or stress.
What are some examples of colocalisation: Some examples of colocalisation include the spatial overlap of different fluorescent markers, such as eGFP and mCherry, in a single image, indicating that different targets are located in the same area of the cell or near each other.
What are the 3 modes in which peptides a: The three modes in which peptides are expressed in neurons are: 1. Type 1: Substantial levels of peptides are synthesized and stored under physiological conditions. 2. Type 2: Peptides are transiently expressed during development. 3. Type 3: Peptides are synthesized and stored under physiological conditions.
When are peptides referred to as neuromo: Peptides are referred to as neuromodulators when they potentiate or depress the effects of another neurotransmitter, such as dopamine or serotonin.
Define: neuromodulator: A neuromodulator is a substance that modifies the effects of other neurotransmitters on a nerve cell without directly affecting the rate of firing or conduction. Neuromodulators can control neurotransmitter synthesis or release in response to stimuli. An example of a neuromodulator is adenosine.
What are neurohormones ?: Neurohormones are chemical messengers produced and released by neuroendocrine cells into the bloodstream, affecting physiological functions and behaviors in the body. They share characteristics with both neurotransmitters and hormones, as they are released by neurons but travel to distant target sites in the body.
What is the pituitary gland ?: The pituitary gland, also known as the hypophysis, is a small, pea-sized endocrine gland located at the base of the brain, beneath the hypothalamus. It is often referred to as the'master gland' because it regulates the function of most other endocrine glands by secreting hormones into the bloodstream.
What controls the release of hormones fr: The release of hormones from the pituitary gland is controlled by the hypothalamus. The hypothalamus produces releasing hormones that stimulate the pituitary gland to release hormones.
What is vasopressin ?: Vasopressin, also known as arginine vasopressin or antidiuretic hormone (ADH), is a naturally occurring hormone produced by the hypothalamus in the brain. It is primarily responsible for regulating the body's fluid balance, blood pressure, and kidney function. Additionally, vasopressin has vasoconstrictive effects and plays a role in regulating the sleep-wake cycle and kidney function.
What are the physiological roles of vaso: Vasopressin, also known as antidiuretic hormone (ADH), plays a crucial role in regulating water and sodium homeostasis through its antidiuretic action on the kidneys. It also plays a role in maintaining plasma volume and osmolality, as well as in regulating blood pressure. Vasopressin also plays a role in regulating systolic and diastolic blood pressure in humans.
What is neuropeptide y ?: Neuropeptide Y (NPY) is a 36-amino acid peptide that belongs to the NPY family of biologically active peptides. It is involved in various physiological and homeostatic processes in both the central and peripheral nervous systems.
What are tachykinins?: Tachykinins are a family of bioactive peptides that play a role in various physiological processes, including inflammation, immunity, and nociception. They are found throughout the nervous system and in nonneural tissues, and are characterized by a common C-terminal sequence. The best-known tachykinin is substance P, which plays a role in pain regulation and has implications for health and disease.
What are the receptors and affinities of: The receptors for tachykinin are NK1, NK2, and NK3, which are part of the G protein-coupled receptor family. The tachykinin with the highest affinity for these receptors is neurokinin B (NKB), while substance P (SP) and neurokinin A (NKA) have lower affinities.
What is substance P ?: Substance P is an 11-amino acid neuropeptide that belongs to the tachykinin family of neuropeptides. It acts as a neurotransmitter and neuromodulator, interacting with neurokinin receptors (NK1, NK2, and NK3) to mediate its biological effects.
What are opioids involved in ?: Opioids are involved in pain relief and are commonly prescribed to treat chronic pain. They bind to opioid receptors in the brain and spinal cord, allowing them to relax the body and relieve pain. However, opioids are also associated with addiction, overdose, and other negative health effects.
Give examples of endogenous opioids: Endogenous opioids include -endorphin, enkephalins, and dynorphins.
What are the 3 propeptide that endogenou: The three propeptides that endogenous peptides are produced from are proenkephalin (PENK), prodynorphin (PDYN), and proopiomelanocortin (POMC).
Give example of an indolamine: An example of an indolamine is serotonin. Serotonin is a neurotransmitter that is involved in mood and sleep regulation.
Give examples of catecholamines: Catecholamines include dopamine (DA), norepinephrine (NE), and epinephrine (EPI).
Give example of an imidazoleamine: An example of an imidazoleamine is histidine, which is an amino acid that contains an imidazole ring with an amine group.
How is dopamine synthesised ?: Dopamine is synthesized in the brain, primarily in the ventral tegmental area and substantia nigra. It is produced by removing a carboxyl group from its precursor, L-DOPA, which is then converted into dopamine.
Is tyrosine an essential or non essentia: Tyrosine is a non-essential amino acid, meaning that the body can synthesize it from another amino acid called phenylalanine. However, it can also be obtained from dietary sources such as meat, dairy products, and fish.
What does alpha- methyl-p-tyrosine do ?: Alpha-methyl-p-tyrosine is an orally active inhibitor of catecholamine synthesis that works by blocking the hydroxylation of tyrosine to dopa. It is effective in controlling hypertensive episodes and symptoms of catecholamine excess in patients with pheochromocytoma, particularly during preparation for surgery.
What is the rate limiting step in dopami: The rate-limiting step in dopamine synthesis is the conversion of L-tyrosine to L-DOPA, which is catalyzed by the enzyme tyrosine hydroxylase.
What drug if administered alongside l-do: Carbidopa is administered alongside l-dopa in the treatment of PD because it prevents the peripheral breakdown of l-dopa, allowing more of it to reach the brain and be converted into dopamine. This combination enhances the effectiveness of l-dopa by ensuring that more of it reaches the brain and is converted into dopamine.
Where is dopamine within neurons ?: Dopamine is synthesized and stored within neurons, primarily in the brain's dopaminergic nuclei, such as the substantia nigra pars compacta, the ventral tegmental area, and the arcuate nucleus.
What happens to dopamine once it\u2019s: Once dopamine is released, it binds to dopamine receptors on target neurons, triggering a response and contributing to feelings of pleasure and motivation. However, dopamine can also be reabsorbed back into the neuron through a process called reuptake, which helps regulate the amount of dopamine in the brain.
What are the dopamine receptors ?: Dopamine receptors are G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) that mediate the effects of dopamine in the body. They belong to the Rhodopsin-like Class A family of 7-transmembrane receptors. There are two main groups of dopamine receptors: D1-like (D1R and D5R) and D2-like (D2R, D3R, and D4R), each with distinct functions and signaling pathways.
How do D1 like receptors work ?: D1-like receptors, which include D1 and D5, are a subfamily of dopamine receptors that are positively coupled to Gs proteins and stimulate adenylyl cyclase activity. This activation leads to an increase in cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels, which mediates various excitatory neurotransmission functions in the central nervous system.
How do D2 like receptors work ?: D2-like receptors are G-protein-coupled receptors that inhibit adenylate cyclase activity, leading to decreased levels of cyclic AMP (cAMP) in the cell. They play a crucial role in regulating dopamine neuron activity, influencing the synthesis, release, and uptake of dopamine. D2-like receptor blockade is also associated with antipsychotic action and extrapyramidal side effects of classical neuroleptics.
How is dopamine reuptaken ?: Dopamine is reuptaken by the dopamine transporter (DAT), which is located on the presynaptic terminal. The DAT transports dopamine from the extracellular space back into the neuron, thereby regulating dopamine levels in the brain.
What do amphetamines do ?: Amphetamines are central nervous system stimulants that increase alertness and energy levels. They are commonly used to treat ADHD and narcolepsy.
How does cocaine work ?: Cocaine works by blocking the reuptake of dopamine, serotonin, and norepinephrine in the brain. This results in increased levels of these neurotransmitters, which leads to feelings of euphoria, increased alertness, and heightened sensations. Repeated use of cocaine can lead to addiction and other negative effects.
What are 2 examples of therapeutic dopam: Two examples of therapeutic dopaminergic drugs are pramipexole and ropinirole.
What is cocaine ?: Cocaine is a powerful stimulant drug derived from the leaves of the coca plant, primarily grown in Bolivia, Peru, and Colombia. It produces intense euphoria and has a high potential for addiction, affecting the brain's dopamine, serotonin, and norepinephrine systems.
What are amphetamines ?: Amphetamines are a class of synthetic drugs that act as stimulants on the central nervous system. They are used to treat medical conditions such as attention deficit disorder, narcolepsy, and obesity. They are also highly addictive and can lead to serious health problems if abused.
What are the 2 pathways involved in dopa: The two pathways involved in dopamine catabolism are monoamine oxidase (MAO) and catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT).
Describe the MAO catabolism pathway for: The MAO catabolism pathway for dopamine involves the enzyme monoamine oxidase (MAO) metabolizing cytosolic dopamine, thereby limiting its auto-oxidation and generating hydrogen peroxide. This process is dependent on MAO anchoring to the outer mitochondrial membrane and shuttling of electrons to the mitochondrial electron transport chain.
Describe the COMT pathway to catabolise: The COMT pathway catabolizes dopamine by converting it into 3-methoxytyramine (3MT), which is then reduced to homovanillic acid (HVA). This process involves the enzyme catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT) donating a methyl group to dopamine, using S-adenosyl methionine (SAM) as a methyl donor. The resulting HVA is eliminated from the body through urine.
Where is MAO found ?: MAO stands for Monoamine Oxidase, which is an enzyme found in the human body. It is primarily found in the brain, liver, and intestines.
What happens to dopac and hva ?: DOPAC (dihydroxyphenylacetic acid) and HVA (homovanillic acid) are metabolites of dopamine, formed through the monoamine oxidase pathway. DOPAC can be further converted into HVA, and their levels in the brain may reflect dopaminergic activity.
What is an example of a MAO inhibitor ?: An example of a MAO inhibitor is selegiline.
